newsitem.title: INDIA: India's overseas shares dive on political crisis.
newsitem.headline: India's overseas shares dive on political crisis.

text.p: Foreign investors caught unawares by a sudden political crisis triggered during the long Easter weekend, marked prices of India's overseas listed equity sharply lower as they returned on Tuesday, traders said.
But they said though prices of global depositary receipts (GDRs) in Hong Kong were quoted at least 10-15 percent below Thursday's close, volumes were low and most investors were on the sidelines.
Prices in London were also expected to open sharply lower.
Largest private firm Reliance Industries was quoting at an indicative $15.25/15.75 in London, against its last close of $17.63/$18.38.
State Bank of India had been driven down to $19.25/19.50 from Thursday's close of $22.25/23.0.

"Prices have been marked down by market makers by around 10-12 percent across-the-board but we are not advising clients to sell when the market is so easy," said a GDR salesman at a leading UK brokerage in London.
"Most investors missed the opportunity to sell yesterday."
A sudden announcement by the Congress party on Sunday that it was withdrawing make-or-break support to the country's ruling coalition sent Indian stock markets into a tailspin on Monday.

Stocks across the country fell more than seven percent but Hong Kong and London markets -- where GDRs of top Indian firms are actively traded -- only reopened on Tuesday after the long Easter weekend.
India's newest GDR -- by state-run telecommunications firm Videsh Sanchar Nigam Ltd (VSNL) -- was quoting at $15.50/16.25 against its last close of $17.50/17.75 in London.
"VSNL has fallen quite a bit considering the amount of strength the issue had and the way the stock traded last week," said the GDR salesman at the UK brokerage.

VSNL raised more than $500 million through an international equity issue late last month. The issue -- India's largest ever GDR offering and its first overseas equity issue this year -- was priced at $13.93 per GDR and traded just under $18 all of last week.
"Obviously prices have been marked down quite sharply," said Manoj Thakkar, subcontinent sales and dealing, at UBS Securities in Hong Kong.
"It's going to be a market completely driven by politics for the next few weeks with prices flying up and down on rumours," Thakkar said.
Prime Minister H.D. Deve Gowda has been given until April 11 to prove his majority in parliament, a near impossible task after his government lost the support of its key ally.
Thakkar said a sudden rally on the Bombay Stock Exchange (BSE) was unlikely to trigger buying in GDRs.
Bombay shares rebounded on Tuesday on news that the government was determined to approve the 1997/98 pro-business budget in parliament, despite the ongoing political crisis.
Bombay's benchmark stocks index was quoting 39.63 points, or 1.2 percent, higher at 3400.52 in afternoon trade.
The market was 2.3 percent higher at one stage, but a statement by the main opposition Bharatiya Janata Party that the budget would not be possible before the confidence vote curtailed the recovery.
